A farmer and a goat are on the left side of a river and must cross by boat.
On the right side of the river, there is a wolf and a cabbage.
The boat can carry only the farmer and a single item.
If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, or the goat would eat the cabbage.
How can the farmer get the goat to the right side of the river without anything being eaten?
Okay, so I've got this classic river crossing puzzle here, and I need to figure out how the farmer can get the goat, wolf, and cabbage across the river without any of them getting eaten. Let me try to break this down step by step.

First, let me list out what each character is:

- Farmer: Can operate the boat, and can carry one item at a time.
- Goat: The main character; we need to get the goat across safely.
- Wolf: Can't be left alone with the goat, so the goat can't be unattended with the wolf.
- Cabbage: Similar issue; if left alone with the goat, the goat will eat the cabbage.

So, the boat can only carry the farmer plus one other item. That means each trip, the farmer can take either the goat, the wolf, or the cabbage, but not multiple items at the same time.

The initial setup is that all four—the farmer, goat, wolf, and cabbage—are on the left side. The right side is empty. The goal is to get all of them to the right without any of the three (wolf, goat, cabbage) being left alone together in a way that causes harm.

Now, on the right, we have the wolf and the goat. If the farmer leaves the goat there, the wolf would eat the goat, which is bad. So, that can't happen.
